Lightweight directory access (like AD) over TCP using SSL/TLS.

column1: BCD store meaning on an MBR Disk

column1: GPT meaning in disk partitioning/boot scheme

installed at the customer’s premises converts the optical signal to an electrical one. Connected to the customer’s router using an RJ45 copper wire patch cord.
Located in a street cabinet. From the OLT- splitters direct each subscriber’s traffic over a short length of fiber to an optical network terminal (ONT) installed at the customer’s premises.
A connection to an internet service provider's (ISP’s) network uses its nearest point of presence (PoP) such as a local telephone exchange.
In a PON- FTTP: a single fiber cable is run from the point of presence to a street cabinet; a splitter directs traffic over a shorter length fiber to ONT on premises.

column1: Small core fiber that carries long wavelength
column3: SMF: supports data rates up to 10 Gbps and cable runs of many kilometers. 8-10 micron core/1310 or 1550 nm wavelength.

column1: Large core fiber that carries shorter wavelengths
column3: MMF: slower signal speeds and shorter distances - better for LANs than WANs. 50 or 62.5 micron core/850 or 1300 nm wavelength. Cheaper.
Low-cost laser used in Multi-mode fiber; faster than LED; good for short-range fiber like 10GBASE-SR

column1: Fiber: bayonet-style connector that uses a push-and-twist locking mechanism
column3: ST: bayonet-style; push-and-twist; used mostly on older multi-mode networks.
SC: simple push/pull insertion. Simplex and Duplex versions (duplex = 2 connectors clipped together). Single or Multi-Mode.
LC: small form factor; Tabbed push/pull design. Small size allows higher port density than SC.

column1: Allows multiple threads to run through the CPU at the same time

column1: Uses ground-basesd long-range fixed access wireless technology & requires unobstructed LoS

column1: Uses a VSAT antenna connected via coax to a DVB-S modem

column1: Requires an antenna with a motor and "phased array" technology

column1: 3G format that allows a removable SIM card in unlocked handsets

column3: CDMA: Area served by each base in 3G refered to as a "cell". Cells have effective range up to 5 miles(8km)

column1: DiplayPort MST meaning and versions (#/#) for daisy chaining

column1: Thunderbolt can daisy chain up to how many devices?
column3: including external GPUs; storage drives; docking stations; and monitors

column1: Thunderbolt 4 supports up to #/# of monitors: 4K at 60Hz/8K at 60Hz
column3: Max speed 40Gbps. A strong choice for users who need ultra-high-definition visuals.

column1: DisplayPort speeds per lane (Original/Current version 2.0 - Gbps)
column3: Up to 4 bonded lanes = max speed of 80Gbps

column1: Next step in wired conn troubleshooting if cables good and connected?
column3: This will verify the integrity of the network interface port by checking that it can receive a signal generated by itself.

column1: Next step if you confirm network cable and interface ports are good?
column3: Could also be a termination or external interference problem.

column1: Final steps in troubleshooting wired connectivity
column3: speed/duplex settings should usually be set to autonegotiate. You can also try updating driver

column1: If the temperature is too high the CPU and other components are likely to do what
column3: Check temperature sensors and fan speeds. Maybe computer needs cleaning or cooling systems need to be replaced or upgraded.

column1: First thing to check in network speed troubleshooting (after narrowing down what they doing)
column3: Use a utility to measure transfer rate independent of specific apps or network services.

column1: What can cause interference in network besides external factors
column3: Check the ends of cables for excessive untwisting of the wire pairs or improper termination. Can also use network tap to look for damaged frames.
